title: Katarina Johnson-Thompson plays down Tokyo 2020 Olympics chances despite World Championship gold
text:
Great Britain’s world heptathlon champion Katarina Johnson-Thompson has played down the notion that she is favourite for Olympic gold at Tokyo 2020.

Johnson-Thompson won her first global outdoor title at the World Athletics Championships in Doha earlier this month with a British record 6,981 points.

The 26-year-old admitted the success has given her a major confidence boost, but she said she expects a fierce reaction from reigning Olympic champion Nafi Thiam after taking the Belgian’s world crown.

We’ll tell you what’s true. You can form your own view. From 15p €0.18 $0.18 USD 0.27 a day, more exclusives, analysis and extras.

Asked if she considered herself to be the front-runner for the Olympics, Johnson-Thompson told BBC 5 Live: “I’m not too sure. I don’t know – it hasn’t settled in.

“For me, even though I’ve won this time around, it’s one of those things – I know that I’m capable of winning now, it has given me confidence for the future, but I know what it’s like to come second. I know what it’s like to feel like you’ve under-performed.

“So I’m fully expecting Nafi to go away and have an amazing winter and come back with a different sort of motivation.”

Johnson-Thompson, nominated for the IAAF World Athlete of the Year award, is bidding to become the third British Olympic heptathlon champion.

She hopes to follow in the footsteps of 2000 winner Denise Lewis and Jessica Ennis-Hill, who won at London 2012, and admitted the two former champions have been major influences on her progress.

“Both Jess and Denise have been vital in my development and motivation and inspiration to do those performances,” said Johnson-Thompson.

“Denise travelled to France when I was looking for a coach in 2016, we travelled to different countries trying to find a coach together.

“And obviously with Jess, I was there in 2012 when she got that British record. That inspired me beyond belief.

“I was only 19 years old at the time and to see that happen first-hand was a huge inspiration, I was like, ‘I want that in the future,’ and I’m just happy and grateful that I was able to put those results down on the track.”

PA
description: Great Britain’s world heptathlon champion Katarina Johnson-Thompson has played down the notion that she is favourite for Olympic gold at Tokyo 2020.
